study_goal: The researchers were examining obesity as a risk factor for COVID-19 susceptibility and severity, not directly evaluating bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results related to bariatric surgery; it focuses on obesity as a risk factor for COVID-19.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity, particularly severe obesity (BMI > 40 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review emergent data on sleeve gastrectomy and bone loss, evidence linking bariatric surgery to fracture risk, and intervention strategies to mitigate surgical bone loss.
results_summary: The study highlights adverse skeletal health outcomes post-bariatric surgery, including bone loss and increased fracture risk, while also discussing potential intervention strategies to address these issues.
population_specificity: Patients planning or undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the benefits and risks of bariatric surgery to guide shared decision-making for patients with severe obesity and related conditions like type 2 diabetes.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery results in greater improvements in weight loss and type 2 diabetes outcomes compared to nonsurgical interventions, with similar safety profiles for sleeve gastrectomy and gastric bypass. Perioperative mortality rates are low (0.03% to 0.2%), and emerging evidence suggests sleeve gastrectomy has fewer reoperations, while gastric bypass may offer more durable weight loss and glycemic control.
population_specificity: Patients with severe obesity (BMI ≥40 or ≥35 with comorbidities) and those with type 2 diabetes (BMI 30-35 with uncontrolled hyperglycemia).
study_duration: At least 5-year follow-up for safety and efficacy comparisons.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the impact of sleeve gastrectomy-induced weight loss on ventilatory function at rest and during exercise in patients with severe obesity.
results_summary: The study found significant weight loss (26.35% of body weight) post-surgery, leading to reduced restrictive respiratory limitations and improved ventilatory efficiency at rest and during exercise.
population_specificity: 46 patients with severe obesity (76% females).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of bariatric surgery on weight loss, glucose metabolism, lipid levels, blood pressure, and quality of life in obese patients, as well as assess nutritional deficiencies post-surgery.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery significantly improved weight, glucose levels, islet function, blood pressure, and lipid profiles within the first 6 months to 1 year, though some rebound occurred by 3 years. Nutritional deficiencies (e.g., vitamin D, calcium, iron) were common post-surgery, but quality of life improved compared to controls.
population_specificity: 20 obese patients in China who underwent bariatric surgery and completed follow-ups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the incidence of internal herniation (IH) after robot-assisted Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RA-RYGB) using the "Double Loop" technique.
results_summary: The study found a low complication rate and no cases of internal herniation in patients who underwent RA-RYGB with the "Double Loop" technique, suggesting its safety and efficacy at a medium-term follow-up. The results were consistent across both primary and revisional procedures.
population_specificity: 129 patients (50.4% primary procedures, 49.6% revisional operations after restrictive bariatric surgery) with a mean age of 47.9 years and mean BMI of 39.7 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether baseline clinical characteristics of patients undergoing sleeve gastrectomy or gastric bypass were associated with unsuccessful weight loss after 12 and 24 months.
results_summary: Older age, larger neck circumference, and lower %EWL at 6 months were significantly associated with unsuccessful weight loss after surgery, with nearly 90% of these patients showing early failure. Age and %EWL at 6 months were predictive of poor outcomes at both 12 and 24 months, while neck circumference was specifically linked to 24-month failure.
population_specificity: 300 patients with morbid obesity who underwent bariatric surgery (sleeve gastrectomy or gastric bypass) with at least 24 months of follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss the implications of NAFLD for surgery, including bariatric surgery, and the challenges in patient management.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery showed favorable results for weight loss and managing NAFLD-related conditions like HCC and ESLD, but the abstract does not provide detailed outcome metrics.
population_specificity: Patients with NAFLD, particularly those with metabolic comorbidities, end-stage liver disease, or hepatocellular carcinoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of fecal microbiota changes in mediating weight loss and metabolic benefits following bariatric surgery (LSG and RYGB).
results_summary: The study found that LSG and RYGB induce procedure-specific changes in fecal microbiota, which may contribute to weight loss and metabolic improvements. Rodent studies suggest the gut microbiome influences immunological, inflammatory, and metabolic pathways, highlighting its potential as a therapeutic target.
population_specificity: Obesity patients undergoing bariatric surgery (LSG or RYGB).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the usefulness of the Edmonton Obesity Staging System (EOSS) for stratifying weight-related health problems, particularly in predicting risks and benefits of bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The EOSS was consistently associated with increased postoperative complications (especially for EOSS 3-4) and inversely associated with weight loss, treatment time, and resolution of hypertension following bariatric surgery. It also predicted mortality outcomes and poorer work outcomes in community populations.
population_specificity: Participants with overweight or obesity in clinical and community settings.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the therapeutic options for childhood obesity, including the role of bariatric surgery in selected cases.
results_summary: The abstract mentions bariatric surgery as a potential treatment strategy for selected cases of childhood obesity, alongside multidisciplinary approaches, but does not provide specific efficacy data.
population_specificity: Children with obesity (selected cases).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between bariatric surgery and all-cause mortality, including cause-specific mortality, in a matched cohort.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was associated with substantially lower all-cause, cardiovascular, and cancer mortality, with significant effects across most subgroups, particularly in men and patients aged 55 or older. The overall mortality rate was 1.4% after a median follow-up of 4.9 years.
population_specificity: 13,679 patients who underwent bariatric surgery in Ontario, Canada, from 2010 to 2016, matched to 13,679 nonsurgical patients by age, sex, BMI, and diabetes duration.

study_goal: To determine the 3-year effects of Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) on blood pressure compared with medical therapy alone in patients with obesity and hypertension.
results_summary: RYGB plus medical therapy resulted in a higher rate of hypertension remission and better BP control with fewer medications compared to medical therapy alone. The surgery was effective for midterm BP control and hypertension remission.
population_specificity: Patients with hypertension receiving at least 2 medications at maximum doses or more than 2 medications at moderate doses and with a BMI between 30.0 and 39.9 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of bariatric surgery on microbiota composition in humans and other vertebrates, evaluate the influence of probiotics on postoperative health, and explore interactions between microbiota and psychological/behavioral factors.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery leads to changes in microbiota composition, including increased abundance of Proteobacteria, but changes in alpha diversity were not specific to the surgery. Probiotics' impact and microbiota-psychological interactions were also investigated.
population_specificity: Humans and other vertebrates (specific subgroups not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the current evidence and guidelines regarding the impact of bariatric surgery on Barrett's esophagus (BE) development, progression, or regression, and its implications for esophageal adenocarcinoma (EAC) management.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery significantly affects BE, with sleeve gastrectomy increasing gastroesophageal reflux and de novo BE risk, while Roux-en-Y gastric bypass may reduce reflux and improve or resolve BE. Current screening practices vary, and there are no established guidelines for BE surveillance post-surgery.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity, particularly those at risk for or diagnosed with Barrett's esophagus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether bariatric surgery reverses neurodegeneration of the optic nerve and impacts retinal and optic nerve structure in obese patients.
results_summary: The study found significant thickening of the retina after bariatric surgery, confined to inner retinal layers, suggesting improved perfusion, but no changes in the ganglion cell layer, choroid, or peripapillary nerve fiber layer thickness. Clinical predictors of retinal thickening included HbA1c variation, preoperative C-peptide, hypertension, OSA, and LDL/TG levels.
population_specificity: Obese patients scheduled for bariatric surgery (40 participants, 80 eyes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bariatric surgery in treating obesity, hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and its potential benefits in reducing chronic kidney disease (CKD) incidence and progression.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery not only aids in weight reduction, blood pressure control, and metabolic improvements but also may reduce CKD incidence and progression. Preclinical studies supported these findings by demonstrating functional, structural, and transcriptomic improvements in kidney injury.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity, hypertension, type 2 diabetes, and chronic kidney disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the reliability of non-invasive vascular unloading (Nexfin®) versus semi-invasive pulse contour analysis (FloTrac™) for continuous cardiac index (CI) measurements in morbidly obese patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that non-invasive CI measurements did not meet interchangeability criteria with semi-invasive methods for monitoring absolute and trending values of CI in bariatric surgery patients. The results were based on correlation, Bland-Altman, and concordance analyses across 10 measurement time points.
population_specificity: Adult morbidly obese patients (mean BMI 49.2 kg/m²) undergoing elective laparoscopic bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of testosterone treatment (TTh) on markers of fat and liver functioning in obese men scheduled for bariatric surgery.
results_summary: TTh in hypogonadal men improved insulin sensitivity, mitochondrial function, and lipid handling in preadipocytes, and reduced NAFLD activity, steatosis scores, and liver triglyceride content compared to untreated hypogonadal men. These effects were comparable to those seen in eugonadal men.
population_specificity: Severely obese, hypogonadal men scheduled for bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of surgical and nonsurgical weight loss on hepatocellular adenoma (HCA) regression in obese patients.
results_summary: The study found that effective long-term weight loss, both surgical and nonsurgical, resulted in regression of HCAs, potentially avoiding major liver resections or reducing morbidity. However, the analysis was limited to a small sample size of 7 patients.
population_specificity: Female patients with hepatocellular adenoma (HCA) and a median preintervention BMI of 41 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an overview of interventions to help women achieve a healthy weight between pregnancies by improving gestational weight gain.
results_summary: The abstract discusses the risks of excessive gestational weight gain and the benefits of limiting it to recommended levels, but does not mention bariatric surgery or its effects.
population_specificity: Women with excessive gestational weight gain and postpartum weight retention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bariatric surgery could help patients with end-stage heart failure (ESHF) and ventricular assist devices (VADs) reduce their BMI below 35 kg/m² to become eligible for heart transplantation.
results_summary: The study included 29 patients and tracked their BMI outcomes post-bariatric surgery, with the composite outcome being achieving a BMI < 35 kg/m². Long-term outcomes were assessed, but specific efficacy details are not provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with end-stage heart failure (ESHF) treated with ventricular assist devices (VADs) and a BMI ≥ 35 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the surgical morbidity of laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) and laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (LRYGB) in obese patients aged 65 years or older.
results_summary: The study found that morbidity and mortality rates of bariatric surgery were low in elderly obese patients. LSG had a lower rate of severe complications compared to LRYGB, though the difference was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Obese patients aged ≥65 years with a BMI between 35.5 and 52.8 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review emerging technologies for obesity treatment, comparing their safety, efficacy, and weight loss outcomes to bariatric surgery and conservative treatments.
results_summary: Emerging therapies showed improved glucose metabolism in diabetic patients and better weight loss than conservative treatments, though not surpassing bariatric surgery, with a low adverse event rate. The study emphasizes multidisciplinary management for new techniques.
population_specificity: General obesity population, including diabetic patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe the incidence and factors associated with severe nutritional complications following adult bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that severe nutritional complications after bariatric surgery are rare but comparable to other major complications, with malnutrition or nutrient deficiency leading to hospital admission being the primary outcome. The majority of patients underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, and the mean preoperative BMI was high (49.3 ± 8.0 kg/m²).
population_specificity: Ontario adults (81.8% female, mean age 45.1 ± 10.6 years) who underwent bariatric surgery between 2009 and 2015.
study_duration: Study period covered surgeries from January 1, 2009, to December 31, 2015.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to update nutritional guidelines for bariatric surgery, focusing on preoperative and postoperative care to address micronutrient deficiencies.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is clinically and cost-effective for severe obesity but can lead to micronutrient deficiencies, necessitating long-term nutritional monitoring and supplementation. Updated guidelines include systematic evidence reviews and recommendations for safe clinical practice.
population_specificity: Adults and adolescents undergoing adjustable gastric band, sleeve gastrectomy, Roux-en-Y gastric bypass, and biliopancreatic diversion/duodenal switch.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bariatric surgery for hypothalamic obesity (HO) in patients with craniopharyngioma (CP).
results_summary: The study found that no generally accepted pharmacologic or bariatric therapy for HO in CP has been effective in randomized controlled trials, and prevention of HO is recommended.
population_specificity: Patients with hypothalamic obesity (HO) caused by craniopharyngioma (CP).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and outcomes of bariatric surgery during the SARS-CoV-2 outbreak and its potential role in minimizing COVID-19 effects in obese patients.
results_summary: The study found a low COVID-19 infection rate (0.6%) post-surgery with no mortality and comparable complication rates to pre-pandemic data, suggesting bariatric surgery remained safe and effective during the outbreak.
population_specificity: Obese patients (BMI > 30) undergoing bariatric surgery in eight high-volume Italian centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the meal-related response of circulating succinate in patients with obesity and type 2 diabetes after bariatric surgery and examine the role of gastrointestinal glucose sensing in succinate dynamics in healthy subjects.
results_summary: The study found that the meal-related response of circulating succinate in patients with obesity and type 2 diabetes improved after metabolic surgery, suggesting a recovery in succinate dynamics post-intervention.
population_specificity: 45 patients with morbid obesity and type 2 diabetes (BMI 39.4 ± 1.9 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bariatric surgery is a suitable treatment for patients with obesity due to confirmed genetic defects (genetic obesity disorders).
results_summary: The study found that in monogenic non-syndromic obesity, genetic defects significantly influence bariatric surgery efficacy, while data for syndromic obesity is scarce and outcomes may be poorer in severe cases. Limited evidence supports bariatric surgery for genetic obesity, but it could be considered a last-resort option for selected patients with life-threatening comorbidities.
population_specificity: Patients with genetic obesity disorders (monogenic non-syndromic and syndromic obesity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the nutritional management and outcomes of bariatric surgery, including pre-operative and post-operative phases, and its impact on weight loss and comorbidity reduction.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery is effective for long-term weight loss and reducing comorbidity burden, but it may lead to nutritional deficiencies and complications. Pre-operative weight loss does not improve post-surgery outcomes, but a modest 5-10% weight loss before surgery may reduce complications. Nutritional counseling and management are crucial post-surgery to address deficiencies and specific issues like dumping syndrome.
population_specificity: Patients with severe obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify factors, beyond weight loss, that influence improvements in health-related quality of life (HRQoL) from before to 5 years after gastric bypass surgery.
results_summary: The study confirmed that weight loss significantly improves HRQoL after bariatric surgery, but preoperative depression medication and postoperative complications were associated with less improvement in HRQoL. Younger patients showed greater improvements in physical health scales, while differences by sex were minor.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent primary gastric bypass surgery in Sweden between 2008 and 2012, with HRQoL data available at baseline and 5-year follow-up (n=6998, 21% men).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the association of bariatric surgery with long-term mortality and the incidence of new-onset obesity-related diseases at a national level.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was associated with reduced all-cause and cardiovascular mortality, as well as a lower incidence of type 2 diabetes, hypertension, dyslipidaemia, and ischemic heart disease. The study pooled data from large-scale population studies but noted limitations like unmeasured variables and heterogeneity in control groups.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity who underwent bariatric surgery (n=269,818) compared to control patients (n=1,270,086).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of bariatric surgery compared to other therapeutic strategies for pediatric obesity.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery, along with other therapeutic strategies like lifestyle correction and drugs, displayed low effectiveness in treating pediatric obesity. Prevention was suggested as a more promising approach than treatment.
population_specificity: Pediatric obesity patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the 30-day complication rates of minimally invasive bariatric surgery between adolescents and adults to assess perioperative safety.
results_summary: The study found that the 30-day complication rate was comparable between adolescents and adults (6.3% vs. 7.3%), with similar rates of intervention, reoperation, readmission, and mortality. The safety profile of bariatric surgery in adolescents was similar to that in adults, supporting its use in adolescents with morbid obesity.
population_specificity: Adolescents (age 19 or younger) and adults undergoing minimally invasive bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether changes in UCP1-3 expressions and their polymorphisms influence weight loss variability after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that UCP2 and UCP3 expressions in adipose tissue and skeletal muscle are affected by bariatric surgery, potentially influencing weight loss, while data on UCP1 remains inconclusive. Polymorphisms in UCP1-3 genes showed contradictory associations with weight loss outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with severe obesity undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the short-term renal effects of bariatric surgery (BS) and compare these effects between two forms of BS: laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) and laparoscopic one anastomosis gastric bypass (OAGB).
results_summary: Both LSG and OAGB resulted in significant reductions in body mass index (-27.1% ± 7.11) and alleviated obesity-related renal changes, though postoperative hyperoxaluria remained a concern, particularly with OAGB. Radiological fat tissue analysis by CT may help predict renal outcomes post-BS.
population_specificity: 57 patients with severe obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if prophylactic use of ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) reduces the incidence of symptomatic gallstone disease after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study is designed to evaluate UDCA's effectiveness in preventing symptomatic gallstone disease post-bariatric surgery, with primary and secondary outcomes including gallstone development, cholecystectomies, side effects, and quality of life. Results were not yet available at the time of the abstract.
population_specificity: Patients with morbid obesity undergoing Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) or sleeve gastrectomy (SG).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify biomarkers of subclinical atherosclerosis in morbidly obese patients and monitor changes in endothelial dysfunction after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Patients with atheromatous plaque had worse cardiovascular risk profiles. Bariatric surgery reduced cardiovascular risk markers like vasa vasorum, oxidized LDL, and plasminogen activator inhibitor-1, with better prognosis for plaque-free patients.
population_specificity: 66 patients with morbid obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent updates on the efficacy, safety, and durability of vertical sleeve gastrectomy (VSG) in adolescents as a treatment for moderate to severe obesity.
results_summary: VSG is effective for weight loss in adolescents, with similar five-year outcomes to adults, and has a complication rate ranging from 0 to 17.5%. The procedure is well-tolerated but remains underutilized despite its benefits.
population_specificity: Adolescents with moderate to severe obesity, particularly those with comorbidities.
study_duration: Five-year follow-up mentioned for weight loss outcomes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of metabolic/bariatric surgery on type 2 diabetes mellitus, cardiovascular risk factors, and cardiovascular mortality.
results_summary: The study found that metabolic/bariatric surgery significantly improves cardiovascular risk factors and may reduce macrovascular events and cardiovascular mortality, though these latter findings require confirmation in randomized clinical trials.
population_specificity: Subjects who underwent metabolic/bariatric surgery between January 1, 2005, and June 1, 2020.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify preoperative modifiable behavioral factors associated with postoperative weight loss outcomes in bariatric surgery patients.
results_summary: The study found mixed associations between preoperative modifiable behaviors (maladaptive eating behaviors, preoperative weight loss, tobacco use) and postoperative weight loss, with most studies reporting no association. Significant heterogeneity in outcome reporting limited quantitative synthesis.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery with at least 2 years of follow-up.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of sleeve gastrectomy (SG) and gastric bypass (GB) in treating obesity and its associated comorbidities.
results_summary: Both SG and GB were effective in weight loss and comorbidity remission, with GB showing higher remission rates for hypertension and dyslipidemia. SG had lower complication rates and shorter surgery duration.
population_specificity: 3287 patients (78.6% female) presenting to a specialized bariatric center for primary bariatric procedures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare weight loss outcomes up to 60 months post-bariatric surgery between patients with high and low preoperative Binge Eating Scale (BES) scores.
results_summary: Patients with higher BES scores initially lost more weight (%TWL) at 24 months, but this difference disappeared by 60 months. Preoperative BES scores, depression, and age were not associated with long-term weight loss outcomes.
population_specificity: 108 Brazilian patients who underwent Roux-en-Y gastric bypass.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of interventions, including bariatric surgery, for managing obesity in individuals with bipolar disorder.
results_summary: No studies met the inclusion criteria, so the effectiveness of bariatric surgery for obesity management in bipolar disorder could not be determined. The review highlights the need for future research in this area.
population_specificity: Individuals with bipolar disorder and comorbid obesity (BMI ≥ 30 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether bariatric surgery reduces diabetic renal, neurological, and ophthalmic complications in patients with obesity/overweight and type 2 diabetes compared to standard medical treatment.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery led to greater reductions in BMI, HbA1c, and urine albumin-creatinine ratio, improved glomerular filtration rate, and enhanced tuning fork vibration sensation, but showed no improvement in 10-g monofilament test, visual acuity, or diabetic retinopathy.
population_specificity: 49 patients with obesity/overweight and type 2 diabetes receiving bariatric surgery, compared to 338 patients receiving standard medical treatment.

study_goal: To evaluate the benefits of bariatric surgery on blood pressure control, particularly in patients with obesity and resistant hypertension.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery led to significant reductions in anti-hypertensive medication use while maintaining blood pressure control, with a notable proportion of hypertension remission compared to usual care. The GATEWAY trial sub-analysis showed a significant decrease in resistant hypertension prevalence after 12 months in the surgical group, unlike the control group.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity and hypertension, particularly those with resistant hypertension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the risk of lithium toxicity following bariatric surgery in patients with bipolar disorder and suggest monitoring and dosage adjustments post-surgery.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery led to lithium toxicity in a patient, causing severe neurological sequelae. It emphasized the need for close lithium level monitoring and potential dosage adjustments post-surgery.
population_specificity: A 39-year-old man with morbid obesity and bipolar affective disorder.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the incidence of gallstone formation between patients treated with ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) versus placebo for 6 months following bariatric surgery.
results_summary: UDCA significantly reduced gallstone formation at 6 months post-surgery compared to placebo. The study had a high dropout rate due to difficulties with medication adherence.
population_specificity: 77.2% women, mean age 42.2 years, pre-surgery BMI 44.4 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how surgeons, including those in bariatric surgery, perceive the value of patient-reported outcome measures (PROMs) in clinical practice.
results_summary: Surgeons in bariatric surgery and other subspecialties found PROMs valuable for enhancing clinical management, patient counseling, and detecting sensitive patient information, but identified obstacles such as implementation challenges and concerns about inappropriate use as performance metrics.
population_specificity: Surgeons from 5 subspecialties (including bariatric surgery) across 3 academic medical centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between bariatric surgery and the long-term incidence of gallstone disease.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery was associated with an increased risk of symptomatic gallstone disease and cholecystectomy, particularly in the first years following treatment, compared to the control group receiving usual obesity care.
population_specificity: 3,597 individuals without previous or concomitant cholecystectomy from 25 surgery departments and 480 primary healthcare centers in Sweden.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of liraglutide compared to placebo on weight loss when added early after laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy (LSG) in obese individuals.
results_summary: Liraglutide significantly augmented weight loss from LSG, with greater %TWL and %EWL compared to placebo, and resolved dysglycemia in all diabetic/pre-diabetic patients in the liraglutide group. However, there was no significant difference in resolution of other obesity-related comorbidities between groups.
population_specificity: Obese individuals with BMI > 30 kg/m² who underwent LSG.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of gut hormones in energy homeostasis, their adaptations in obesity and after weight loss, and the potential of gut hormone-based therapies for obesity treatment, including insights from bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery leads to profound weight loss and metabolic improvements, likely due to adaptive alterations in gut hormone levels. It also highlighted the potential of gut hormone-based therapies, particularly dual or triple receptor agonists, to mimic these effects and improve obesity and glycaemia management.
population_specificity: Obese individuals and those with hyperglycaemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of bariatric surgery on male obesity-associated gonadal dysfunction, focusing on its effects on serum testosterone concentrations and spermatogenesis.
results_summary: The study found that weight loss after bariatric surgery correlates with increased serum testosterone concentrations, surpassing results from lifestyle modifications alone. However, data on sperm and semen parameters remain controversial, and emerging evidence suggests paternal obesity can affect offspring metabolic and reproductive phenotypes via epigenetic reprogramming.
population_specificity: Men of reproductive age with obesity and associated infertility.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between prior bariatric surgery and perioperative cardiovascular outcomes following noncardiac surgery in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: The study found that prior bariatric surgery was associated with a reduced risk of major adverse cardiovascular and cerebrovascular events (MACCEs), death, acute kidney injury, and acute respiratory failure in T2DM patients undergoing noncardiac surgery. The incidence of MACCEs was significantly lower in patients with prior bariatric surgery (1.01%) compared to those with morbid obesity (3.25%).
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus undergoing major noncardiac surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of bariatric surgery versus lifestyle intervention for treating obesity, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and nonalcoholic steatohepatitis.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is the only proven effective treatment for these metabolic disorders, whereas lifestyle intervention alone results in modest weight loss at mid and long term. However, bariatric surgery is offered to only a small percentage of patients due to its invasiveness and cost.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity, type 2 diabetes mellitus, and nonalcoholic steatohepatitis.

study_goal: To develop evidence-based recommendations and expert consensus for nutrition management of patients undergoing bariatric surgery and postoperative follow-up.
results_summary: The study recommends preoperative micronutrient screening, a VLCD for 4-8 weeks prior to surgery, a liquid diet postoperatively for a month followed by a semi-solid diet, adjusted protein intake, systematic multivitamin supplementation, higher doses of calcium citrate and vitamin D, and individualized use of proton-pump inhibitors. Specialized follow-up is emphasized for high-risk groups.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery, with specific focus on pregnant women, teenagers, and elderly patients.
effective_dosage: Protein (1-1.5 g/kg adjusted weight), higher doses of calcium citrate and vitamin D (specific amounts not stated).
study_duration: Preoperative VLCD for 4-8 weeks, postoperative liquid diet for 1 month, semi-solid diet for 1 month.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of bariatric surgery as a therapeutic approach for obesity-induced heart failure with preserved ejection fraction (HFpEF).
results_summary: The study suggests that substantial weight reduction through bariatric surgery is a promising therapeutic approach for obesity-induced HFpEF, alongside lesser weight reduction via caloric restriction. Obesity-associated inflammation may contribute to HFpEF, and weight reduction interventions could mitigate these effects.
population_specificity: Middle-aged and elderly individuals with obesity and HFpEF, particularly noting differences in demographics (e.g., African American women) and comorbidities compared to elderly patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of bariatric surgery on the pharmacology of oral anticoagulants, particularly direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs).
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery reduces vitamin K antagonist (VKA) requirements for the same INR target but raises concerns about insufficient efficacy of dabigatran after gastric bypass. Rivaroxaban at prophylactic doses showed no impact post-surgery, but data for other anticoagulants or therapeutic DOAC doses remain inconclusive.
population_specificity: Patients who have undergone bariatric surgery, particularly those requiring oral anticoagulants.
effective_dosage: Dabigatran 150 mg twice daily; rivaroxaban 10 mg per day.
study_duration: Follow-up ranged from 3 days to 8 months post-surgery.
interactions: Potential impaired absorption of dabigatran after gastric bypass; no significant impact noted for rivaroxaban at prophylactic doses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to consolidate current understanding of the metabolic, macrovascular, and microvascular benefits of bariatric surgery and provide an update on its effects.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery improves obesity-related metabolic comorbidities, including dyslipidaemia, hypertension, T2DM, and inflammation, while also slowing atherosclerosis and reducing cardiovascular and all-cause mortality. Early metabolic benefits vary by surgery type, while long-term effects correlate with sustained weight loss.
population_specificity: Individuals with morbid obesity and related metabolic conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize recent advances in hormonal and nutritional strategies for appetite control, including the role of appetite-control hormones in the efficacy of bariatric procedures.
results_summary: The study highlights that appetite-control hormones play a role in the efficacy of bariatric procedures, suggesting these procedures may help regulate energy intake. However, long-term safety and physiological mechanisms of some nutritional strategies remain unclear.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion of appetite control mechanisms and bariatric surgery)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the necessity of resuming bariatric/metabolic surgery post-pandemic and proposed a priority ranking plan for patient selection.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery provides prompt, lasting benefits for obesity and diabetes, which are major risk factors for severe Covid-19. It recommended resuming surgery with priority-based patient selection and strict infection control measures.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity, particularly those with diabetes, who are candidates for bariatric/metabolic surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of regional adiposity in HFpEF and evaluate strategies like bariatric surgery for reducing adiposity and improving HFpEF-related outcomes.
results_summary: The study suggests that regional fat distribution, particularly epicardial and visceral fat, strongly associates with HFpEF risk. Bariatric surgery, along with exercise and diet, shows promise in reducing adiposity, but few studies focus on HFpEF-related outcomes in obese populations.
population_specificity: Obese individuals, particularly those with or at risk for HFpEF.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review recent findings on postoperative outcomes of bariatric and metabolic surgery, focusing on weight loss, remission of obesity-related diseases, reflux, revisional surgery, robotic-assisted platforms, and adolescent populations.
results_summary: Sleeve gastrectomy (SG) and Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) showed similar weight loss at 5 years, while duodenal switch (BPD/DS) achieved maximal weight loss and optimal comorbidity resolution. Surgery provided significant protection against coronary artery disease and heart failure, but SG was associated with high rates of postoperative GERD.
population_specificity: Adults and adolescents with obesity or obesity-related comorbidities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a laparoscopically guided surgical TAP and RS block in reducing analgesic consumption and improving functional outcomes in patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study is ongoing, and results are not yet reported; it focuses on comparing postoperative narcotic use, pain scores, functional outcomes, and quality of recovery between intervention and placebo groups.
population_specificity: 150 patients living with obesity undergoing elective laparoscopic Roux-En-Y gastric bypass.
effective_dosage: 60 mL 0.25% ropivacaine, divided into four injections (two for TAP and two for RS block).
study_duration: 6 months (recruitment period; intervention duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the percentage of T2DM patients meeting DSS-II eligibility criteria for bariatric surgery, their awareness of BS as an option, and associated characteristics.
results_summary: The study found that eligibility rates for BS in T2DM patients remain low, with limited data on how many eligible patients are informed about BS. It also examined demographic and clinical factors linked to eligibility and awareness.
population_specificity: T2DM patients visiting outpatient clinics at three large-volume university hospitals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the incidence of gallstone formation after prophylactic administration of ursodeoxycholic acid (UDCA) in patients undergoing one anastomosis gastric bypass (OAGB).
results_summary: The study found that UDCA administration significantly reduced gallstone incidence (4.2% in the UDCA group vs. 25.2% in the control group) after OAGB, with no reported intolerance. No significant difference in quality of life scores was observed between the groups.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing one anastomosis gastric bypass (OAGB).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of bariatric surgery in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) patients and its impact on IBD course.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery has an acceptable safety profile in IBD patients, with pooled adverse event rates of 15.9% (early) and 16.9% (late). Efficacy was demonstrated by a 66.1% excess weight loss and 13.7 kg/m² BMI reduction at 12 months, with nearly half of patients reducing IBD medications.
population_specificity: Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) patients undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the transversus abdominis plane (TAP) block provides effective postoperative analgesia in patients undergoing bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that TAP block significantly reduced pain scores at rest up to 24 postoperative hours compared to the control group, though dynamic pain scores and morphine consumption at 2 hours were not significantly different. Block-related complications were not significantly different between groups, and the overall evidence quality was moderate-to-low.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery (1,025 participants across 13 trials).
study_duration: Postoperative outcomes assessed up to 24 hours.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore patients' and healthcare professionals' experiences with integrating patient-reported outcome monitoring (PRO/CFS) into bariatric surgery care.
results_summary: The study describes a planned implementation of PRO/CFS in bariatric outpatient clinics, focusing on HRQOL, mental health, and other outcomes, but does not yet report specific findings on efficacy or outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery at two outpatient clinics.
study_duration: Assessments at pre-surgery, 3 months, and 12 months post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of genetic testing and personalized nutrition in managing micronutrient deficiencies associated with bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Studies found associations between genetic variants and micronutrient metabolism, suggesting genetic testing could predict outcomes in bariatric surgery patients. However, research on genetic variants specific to bariatric surgery and micronutrient deficiencies remains limited.
population_specificity: Morbidly obese individuals undergoing or having undergone bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility, safety, and efficacy of robotic-assisted management (magnetic sphincter augmentation or conversion to Roux-en-Y gastric bypass) for treating intractable GERD following sleeve gastrectomy.
results_summary: The study found that robotic-assisted approaches for GERD post-sleeve gastrectomy had low morbidity and high success rates (>80% PPI discontinuation), with no significant differences in intraoperative/postoperative morbidity between groups, though operative times varied.
population_specificity: Patients with GERD after sleeve gastrectomy (MSA-S and RYGB groups) or GERD without prior bariatric surgery (MSA group) at a tertiary-care bariatric center (2015–2019).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the clinical features, diagnosis, and treatment of Wernicke's encephalopathy, particularly highlighting non-traditional causes such as post-bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The abstract notes that Wernicke's encephalopathy, caused by thiamine deficiency, is increasingly recognized in non-alcoholic populations, including post-bariatric surgery patients, and emphasizes the importance of early diagnosis and treatment to prevent permanent disability.
population_specificity: Patients following bariatric surgery, gastrointestinal surgery, cancer, and pancreatitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of bariatric surgery on health-related quality of life (HRQL) and compare the evidence available on physical and mental health outcomes post-surgery.
results_summary: The study found that physical aspects of HRQL improve more than mental health aspects after bariatric surgery, with peak benefits observed 1-2 years post-surgery. However, comparative HRQL analyses between procedures were limited due to a lack of randomized data, and qualitative research highlighted patient tensions post-surgery.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing bariatric surgery (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of metabolic surgery in treating type 2 diabetes and its complications, while identifying gaps in current knowledge.
results_summary: The study found that metabolic surgery is superior to medical therapy alone for achieving glycaemic and metabolic targets in type 2 diabetes, with potential benefits for diabetic kidney disease. However, effects on complications like retinopathy or neuropathy remain uncertain, with possible post-operative deterioration.
population_specificity: Patients with obesity-associated type 2 diabetes, including those with and without complications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine changes in energy and macronutrient intake after bariatric surgery and establish nutritional guidelines for achieving target weight loss.
results_summary: The study found that successful weight loss after bariatric surgery was associated with lower carbohydrate and fat intake, with specific cutoff values for calorie and protein intake at different postoperative intervals. Compliance with these nutrient recommendations was linked to long-term weight loss success.
population_specificity: 189 morbidly obese patients who underwent bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe possible complications, ailments, and important follow-up considerations after bariatric surgery to improve long-term outcomes.
results_summary: Bariatric surgery is effective and durable for obesity treatment but is associated with surgical and medical complications, including dumping syndrome and malnutrition. Adequate lifelong monitoring is crucial for reducing complications and achieving lasting results.
population_specificity: Severely obese patients who failed non-surgical weight loss interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review predictive factors for outcomes of bariatric surgery, including weight loss, weight regain, diabetes remission, and recurrence, to improve patient selection and post-operative care.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery is effective for weight loss and comorbidity reduction but outcomes vary among patients. Post-operative behaviors and lifestyle changes are more influential than pre-operative predictors for long-term success.
population_specificity: Patients with severe obesity undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify expected pharmacokinetic changes and provide practical recommendations for medication management of chronic diseases after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that pharmacokinetic changes after bariatric surgery vary by surgery type and provided guiding principles for medication management, along with practice tips for specific chronic disease states. It concluded that long-term medication regimens should be adjusted in an evidence-based manner post-surgery.
population_specificity: Human adults undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review surgical techniques in gastric surgery and describe imaging appearances of postoperative changes and complications.
results_summary: The study highlights the challenges of interpreting imaging after gastric surgery due to anatomical modifications and emphasizes the importance of recognizing normal postoperative changes and complications. It reviews various surgical techniques but does not provide specific efficacy or safety outcomes for bariatric surgery.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent gastric surgery (not specifically bariatric surgery).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether butorphanol, a KOR agonist, could protect pulmonary function in obese patients undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.
results_summary: Butorphanol improved oxygenation and reduced dead space ventilation compared to the control group, with lower levels of pulmonary injury biomarkers postoperatively, though the incidence of PPCs was similar between groups.
population_specificity: Obese patients (BMI ≥ 30 kg/m²) undergoing laparoscopic bariatric surgery.
study_duration: Measured at 1h after operation start, end of operation, 1h after extubation, and postoperatively at 3h, 6h, 12h, and 24h.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the neurobiological aspects of obesity causation and treatment, focusing on the effectiveness of bariatric surgery and GLP-1R agonist therapies in influencing food reward and motivational drive to overeat.
results_summary: The study highlights that bariatric surgery and GLP-1R agonist therapies effectively target the pathophysiology of obesity by modulating brain appetitive control circuits, reducing hyperphagia, and improving weight loss outcomes compared to behavioral therapy alone.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and outcomes of bariatric surgery in patients with paraplegia and severe obesity, given the lack of existing evidence for this specific population.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery led to significant weight loss, improved mobility, and enhanced quality of life in patients with paraplegia, with no significant post-operative complications reported in the reviewed cases.
population_specificity: Patients with severe obesity and paraplegia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare weight loss outcomes and long-term effects of non-banded versus banded Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (B-RYGB) in superobese patients (BMI ≥50 kg/m²).
results_summary: The study will evaluate weight loss, non-response rates, reduction of obesity-related comorbidities, complications, and patient satisfaction over a 10-year follow-up period, but results are not yet provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Superobese patients (BMI ≥50 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: A 7.0-8.0 cm silastic ring (MiniMizer®) placed proximal to the gastrojejunostomy for B-RYGB.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the latest developments in bariatric endoscopy, including primary and secondary procedures, to address the treatment gap for obesity classes not adequately served by surgery.
results_summary: The study highlights that bariatric surgery provides sustainable results for morbid obesity, while endoscopic procedures offer less invasive alternatives for lower and middle obesity classes and help manage complications from bariatric surgeries. Innovative endoscopic techniques and implants are emerging as effective tools in obesity treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with morbid obesity and lower/middle obesity classes (defined by BMI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of enteral nutrition (EN) versus total parenteral nutrition (TPN) in treating postoperative upper gastrointestinal fistula (PUGIF) following bariatric surgery and other major upper GI surgeries.
results_summary: The study hypothesizes that EN increases the 30-day fistula closure rate in PUGIF, improving health-related quality of life without increasing morbidity or mortality, but results are pending as it is a planned randomized trial.
population_specificity: Patients with PUGIF after esophagogastric resection (including bariatric surgery), duodenojejunal resection, or pancreatic resection with digestive tract violation.
study_duration: Outcomes assessed at 30 days and 6 months post-randomization.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-term impact of sleeve gastrectomy (SG) on cardiac autonomic function (CAF) and its relationship with weight loss in women with obesity.
results_summary: SG was effective at reducing excess weight and improving heart rate variability (HRV) within the first month after surgery, with these improvements detectable as early as one month post-operation. HRV assessment showed promise as a low-cost tool for monitoring these changes.
population_specificity: 23 female patients with obesity (mean age 36.0 ± 11.1 years, BMI 35.1 ± 3.4 kg/m²).
study_duration: 3 months (assessed pre-surgery and at 1 and 3 months post-surgery).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of endoscopy before and after bariatric surgery for managing adiposity and related chronic diseases.
results_summary: The study issued a position statement based on clinical knowledge, expert opinion, and peer-reviewed evidence, but specific outcomes or effects of bariatric surgery were not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients seeking surgery for adiposity-based chronic diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether weight loss alone or metabolic changes from bariatric surgery were responsible for reduced cancer risk in obese populations.
results_summary: The study found that bariatric surgery reduced cancer risk by approximately 50% in participants with 20% to 34.9% total weight loss compared to those with <20%. Improvements in glucose, proinsulin, insulin, leptin, and ghrelin levels were also associated with decreased cancer risk.
population_specificity: 2,458 participants (79% female, mean age 46) from ten U.S. clinical facilities.
study_duration: Follow-up over 8,759 person-years (measurements taken preoperatively and 1 year postoperatively).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether routine preoperative esophagogastroduodenoscopy (p-EGD) should be performed before bariatric surgery by analyzing its impact on surgical plans and patient outcomes.
results_summary: The study found that for 82% of patients, routine p-EGD did not alter the surgical plan or postpone surgery, while 16% required changes or delays, and 0.4% had absolute contraindications. The findings question the necessity of routine p-EGD due to its invasive nature and unclear effectiveness.
population_specificity: Obese patients undergoing bariatric surgery (10,685 patients across 25 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether postoperative administration of GLP-1 analogues could enhance weight loss and comorbidity improvements in patients with unsatisfactory results after bariatric surgery.
results_summary: The study found that GLP-1 analogues may promote additional weight loss and type 2 diabetes remission postoperatively, suggesting potential benefits for patients with suboptimal outcomes after bariatric surgery. However, only one randomized controlled trial was identified among the reviewed studies.
population_specificity: Patients with severe obesity who underwent bariatric surgery and had unsatisfactory long-term results.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the history, current state, and future of bariatric and metabolic surgery, including endoscopic treatments for obesity, and to discuss challenges and recommendations for expanding patient eligibility.
results_summary: The study found that both surgical and endoscopic treatments for obesity lead to significant weight loss and comorbidity reduction, though broader implementation and updated patient selection criteria are needed. Long-term improvements in morbidity and mortality have been achieved, but further enhancements are possible.
population_specificity: Individuals with obesity (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: To assess the availability and distribution of specialized public obesity care services, including bariatric surgery, across Italy.
results_summary: The study found an uneven distribution of obesity-focused facilities in Italy, with an inverse correlation between regional obesity prevalence and facility availability. Surgery-oriented centers were more widely distributed than medically oriented ones, but insufficient data was available for a detailed analysis of their characteristics.
population_specificity: Italian healthcare system and regional obesity care services.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the critical components and considerations for optimal nutrition care in patients undergoing bariatric surgery, focusing on pre- and postoperative phases.
results_summary: The study highlights that bariatric surgery is the most effective treatment for severe obesity but notes varying risks of nutrient deficiencies based on surgery type and nutrition intervention. It emphasizes the role of a specialized dietitian in achieving and maintaining optimal nutrition status and calls for lifelong follow-up.
population_specificity: Patients with severe and complex obesity undergoing bariatric surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sleeve gastrectomy (SG) is non-inferior to Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (RYGB) in terms of total body weight loss in adolescents with severe obesity.
results_summary: The abstract does not report results, as the study is ongoing. The primary outcome will measure the proportion of participants achieving 20% total body weight loss at 3 years postoperatively, with secondary outcomes including changes in BMI, adverse health events, comorbidity resolution, and quality of life.
population_specificity: Adolescents aged 13-17 (Tanner stage ≥IV) with severe obesity.
study_duration: Follow-up extends into the long term, with primary outcome measured at 3 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short and long-term results of revisional bariatric surgery for insufficient weight loss or weight regain after laparoscopic Roux-en-Y gastric bypass (LRYGB).
results_summary: The study found that banded bypass provided modest additional weight loss and helped patients with dumping syndrome, while biliopancreatic diversion (BPD) achieved greater weight loss but had a higher reoperation risk. Revisional surgery was rare but effective in carefully selected cases.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent revisional bariatric surgery after LRYGB for insufficient weight loss (n=54).
study_duration: Follow-up of at least 1 year (revisional surgery performed 3.3 ± 2.3 years after LRYGB in the banded group and 6.4 ± 4.3 years in the BPD group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if dietary supplementation with Benfotiamine could help control blood glucose in patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding Benfotiamine's effects on blood glucose control or other outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).

study_goal: To determine the effects of long-term benfotiamine supplementation on peripheral nerve function and inflammatory markers in type 1 diabetes patients.
results_summary: Benfotiamine significantly increased thiamine levels but showed no significant effects on peripheral nerve function or inflammatory biomarkers compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Patients with type 1 diabetes (n=67, 59 completed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Berberine improves non-motor symptoms (depression and gastrointestinal dysfunction) in a Parkinson's disease rat model.
results_summary: Berberine improved depression-like behaviors, increased dopamine and serotonin in the midbrain, enhanced gastrointestinal function, and modulated enteric neurotransmitters and glial cells in Parkinson's disease rats.
population_specificity: 6-hydroxydopamine-induced (6-OHDA) Parkinson's disease rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Benfotiamine could prevent or reverse early-stage diabetic nephropathy in experimental and clinical settings.
results_summary: Benfotiamine prevented early-stage diabetic nephropathy in experimental studies but failed to produce similar clinical effects in human trials. The abstract suggests possible explanations for this discrepancy but does not detail them.
population_specificity: Diabetic rats and patients with type 2 diabetes and microalbuminuria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of combining Berberine (BBR) with anti-PD-L1 on hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) tumorigenesis, proliferation, migration, and invasion.
results_summary: BBR significantly inhibited HCC cell proliferation, and its combination with anti-PD-L1 markedly suppressed tumorigenesis, migration, and invasion by inactivating Erk phosphorylation. The treatment also affected immune subsets in tumors.
population_specificity: Hep-3B and HCCLM3 hepatocellular carcinoma cell lines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore berberine's therapeutic potential in mitigating metabolic dysfunction-associated steatotic liver disease (MASLD) and elucidate its mechanisms of action, focusing on glucose and lipid metabolism modulation via PI3K/Akt and STING pathways.
results_summary: Berberine significantly reduced hepatic steatosis, inflammation, and glucose intolerance, improved insulin sensitivity, and modulated lipid metabolism genes by activating PI3K/Akt and suppressing STING pathways in both in vivo and in vitro models.
population_specificity: Male C57BL/6J mice and HepG2 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the effects of Berberine (BBR) on depression by reviewing in vitro and in vivo experiments to assess its potential as a multi-target antidepressant.
results_summary: BBR demonstrated indirect antidepressant properties by modulating gut microbiota, strengthening the intestinal barrier, increasing short-chain fatty acid-producing bacteria, and regulating tryptophan metabolism. It also showed antidepressant-like effects via pathways such as Nrf2/ARE, HPA axis, and PPAR-delta, though further clinical trials are needed.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo studies reviewed, no human population detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate and compare the effectiveness of berberine (BER) and ellagic acid (EA), alone and in combination, in treating hind limb ischemia-reperfusion (I/R) injury in rats.
results_summary: Berberine reduced oxidative stress markers (MDA), increased antioxidant levels (GSH, SOD, CAT), normalized apoptosis (Bax, Bcl-2) and pyroptosis (Nrf2, NLRP3, Gasdermin D) pathways, and reduced histopathological damage in muscle tissue. The combination of BER and EA showed the most significant reduction in damage.
population_specificity: Male Sprague Dawley rats with induced hind limb I/R injury.
effective_dosage: 200 mg/kg, intraperitoneal (single dose at the 75th minute of ischemia).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a brain-targeted delivery system using berberine-inspired ionizable lipids to improve BBB penetration and nucleic acid stability for neurological disease therapy.
results_summary: The study found that berberine-inspired nanoparticles enhanced brain uptake, improved nucleic acid stability, and showed therapeutic potential in murine models of Alzheimer's disease, glioma, and cryptococcal meningitis. The system also demonstrated minimal immunogenicity and inherent neuroprotective properties.
population_specificity: Murine models (mice)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of berberine (BBR) combined with ferulic acid (FA) in a microneedle syringe for treating psoriasis by enhancing drug delivery and modulating inflammatory responses.
results_summary: The microneedle syringe improved transepidermal drug delivery, and BBR-FA nanoparticles inhibited microbial proliferation, scavenged reactive oxygen species, suppressed keratinocyte growth, and modulated macrophage polarization to reduce inflammation.
population_specificity: Patients with psoriasis (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a salt formulation of berberine (BBR) and quercetin (QR) (BQS) could enhance their combined anti-fibrotic effects in liver fibrosis compared to a physical mixture (BQP).
results_summary: BQS significantly improved the dissolution efficiency and bioavailability of QR, matching BBR levels, and demonstrated superior anti-fibrotic effects in both human hepatic stellate cells (LX-2) and a mouse model of hepatic fibrosis by modulating lipid accumulation, inflammation, apoptosis, and the cell cycle.
population_specificity: Human hepatic stellate cell line LX-2 and mice with methionine and choline-deficient (MCD) diet-induced hepatic fibrosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether exercise, berberine, or their combination could improve MAFLD by modulating gut microbiota and hepatic fatty acid beta-oxidation.
results_summary: Berberine effectively reduced liver lipid accumulation, restored gut microbiota diversity, and upregulated hepatic fatty acid beta-oxidation proteins (ACOX1, HMGCS2, CPT-1α), with the combined intervention showing the most significant effects.
population_specificity: Mice fed a high-fat diet to induce MAFLD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the synergistic potential of berberine (BBR) and curcumin (CUR) co-crystals in a nanohydrogel formulation for enhanced therapeutic delivery and dual targeting mechanisms in endometrial cancer.
results_summary: The CUR/BBR nanohydrogel demonstrated superior efficacy with an IC50 of 12.36 μg/mL against HEC-59 endometrial cancer cells, outperforming individual components and Camptothecin. The dual binding mechanism of CUR and BBR enhanced apoptotic activity by disrupting caspase-3 functions.
population_specificity: HEC-59 endometrial cancer cells (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Not specified (IC50 reported as 12.36 μg/mL for the nanohydrogel formulation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the renoprotective effects of berberine and elucidate its molecular mechanisms in treating various renal diseases.
results_summary: The study found that berberine exhibits a broad spectrum of pharmacological activities, including antioxidant properties, blood glucose reduction, lipid modulation, and anti-inflammatory effects, with significant potential for treating renal diseases like diabetic nephropathy, renal fibrosis, and kidney toxicity. It also highlighted berberine's wide therapeutic safety margin when administered orally.
population_specificity: Patients with renal diseases, including diabetic nephropathy, renal fibrosis, renal aging, and kidney toxicity induced by chemotherapy and antibiotics.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanisms of action of berberine and its clinical relevance in managing dermatologic diseases.
results_summary: The study highlights berberine's broad pharmacological properties, including antioxidant effects and gut microbiome regulation, suggesting its potential for treating complex skin disorders like acne, psoriasis, and skin aging.
population_specificity: Not specified (general dermatologic conditions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the combination of Berberine (BBR) and caffeine (CAF) offers neuroprotective effects against Parkinson's disease (PD)-related impairments compared to metformin (MTF) in a rotenone-induced rat model.
results_summary: The combination of BBR and CAF prevented motor deficits, weight reduction, dopamine depletion, and monoamine oxidase activity, while reducing inflammation and α-synuclein aggregation. It also normalized tyrosine hydroxylase levels and increased protein phosphatase 2A activity, showing superior neuroprotective effects compared to monotherapy or MTF.
population_specificity: Rotenone-induced rat model of Parkinson's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and safety of berberine liposome-modified bone cement in treating Staphylococcus aureus-induced osteomyelitis in a rat model.
results_summary: The berberine liposome-modified bone cement showed favorable biodegradability, sustained drug release (over 90% within 14 days), effective biofilm eradication (up to 80%), and facilitated bone repair (80% bone volume fraction). The treatment demonstrated efficacy in addressing tibial osteomyelitis in rats.
population_specificity: Rat model of Staphylococcus aureus-induced osteomyelitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the protective effects of berberine on myocardial tissue in a rat model of ischemia-reperfusion injury and explore the role of the miR-184/NOTCH1 signaling pathway.
results_summary: Berberine significantly reduced myocardial infarct size, improved hemodynamic parameters, and attenuated apoptosis. The miR-184 inhibitor also demonstrated protective effects by modulating key signaling pathways involved in myocardial injury.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the neuroprotective effects of berberine chloride (BC) against aluminium chloride-induced Alzheimer's disease in zebrafish larvae by examining oxidative stress and neuroinflammation.
results_summary: BC mitigated biochemical and behavioral changes induced by AlCl3, reduced cholesterol and triglyceride levels, and interacted with the ABCA1 protein, suggesting potential as a therapeutic agent for Alzheimer's disease.
population_specificity: Zebrafish larvae
effective_dosage: Up to 40 μM (no developmental abnormalities), LC50 at 50.16 μM

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the safety and efficacy of berberine ursodeoxycholate (HTD1801) in patients with type 2 diabetes inadequately controlled by diet and exercise.
results_summary: HTD1801 significantly reduced HbA1c levels in a dose-dependent manner, improved glycemic and cardiometabolic parameters, and was well tolerated with mostly mild adverse events. The 1000 mg dose also showed reductions in lipids and liver injury markers.
population_specificity: Patients with type 2 diabetes (mean age 54.3 years, 63.7% male) in China with HbA1c levels of 7.0% to 10.5% and fasting plasma glucose <250.5 mg/dL.
effective_dosage: 500 mg twice daily and 1000 mg twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore berberine's protective effects against rheumatoid arthritis (RA) and clarify the role of ATF3 in its mechanism of action.
results_summary: Berberine reduced proinflammatory cytokines and MMPs in LPS-stimulated synovial cells and CIA mice, mediated by ATF3 induction and AMPK activation. ATF3 knockdown reversed these effects, while AMPK activation replicated berberine's benefits.
population_specificity: LPS-stimulated SW982 human synovial cell line and collagen-induced arthritis (CIA) mouse model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antibacterial mechanism of Berberine (BBR) against the community-associated MRSA strain USA300 LAC and its potential synergy with Oxacillin.
results_summary: BBR compromised the cell wall integrity of USA300 LAC by inhibiting the tarO gene, suppressing wall teichoic acid (WTA) biosynthesis, and upregulating lytic enzymes LytM and SsaA, leading to peptidoglycan hydrolysis. Additionally, BBR synergistically enhanced the antibacterial effect of Oxacillin against USA300 LAC.
population_specificity: In vitro study on the MRSA strain USA300 LAC.
interactions: Synergistic effect with Oxacillin mentioned; no other interactions noted.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between telomerase activity (RTA) and metabolites/metabolic pathways in HCT 116 colorectal cancer cells treated with berberine.
results_summary: Berberine treatment impacted RTA in HCT 116 cells, correlating with 14 metabolites (positively) and 2 metabolites (negatively). Glutamic acid was consistently linked to RTA, and four metabolic pathways involving glutamic acid/glutamine were identified as majorly affected.
population_specificity: Colorectal cancer cell line HCT 116.
study_duration: Not specified (cells harvested at different time points).

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine whether berberine hydrochloride (BBH) could inhibit Ostreid herpesvirus 1 (OsHV-1) infection in blood clams (Anadara broughtonii).
results_summary: A 3 mg/L BBH bath immersion significantly suppressed OsHV-1 replication in blood clams, reduced viral gene expression early in infection, and increased survival rates to 46.67% compared to 100% mortality in untreated clams.
population_specificity: Blood clams (Anadara broughtonii) infected with OsHV-1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the mechanism of action of berberine against Streptococcus suis meningitis by identifying potential targets and signaling pathways.
results_summary: Berberine showed protective effects against S. suis meningitis by regulating inflammatory response and oxidative stress, with key targets including TLR4, FN1, SOD1, and CAT. Molecular docking confirmed strong binding activity between berberine and TLR4/FN1.
population_specificity: Humans and pigs (in vitro/computer-based analysis, not clinical trial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Berberine's role in modulating intestinal microbiota and its potential therapeutic effects on metabolic disorders and inflammatory diseases.
results_summary: Berberine promotes beneficial bacteria growth (e.g., Bacteroides, Bifidobacterium, Lactobacillus) and reduces harmful bacteria (e.g., Escherichia coli). It improves blood glucose levels, lipid profiles, and reduces chronic inflammation, particularly when combined with probiotics, and shows promise in treating inflammatory intestinal disorders.
population_specificity: Clinical and preclinical studies (specific population not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and underlying mechanisms of Berberine (BBR) in treating recurrent Clostridioides difficile infection (rCDI) using mouse and organoid models.
results_summary: BBR treatment reduced infection severity, improved survival rates, alleviated intestinal epithelial damage, suppressed inflammatory pathways, and reshaped gut microbiota by increasing beneficial bacteria and short-chain fatty acids.
population_specificity: Vancomycin-dependent rCDI mouse model and intestinal organoids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether berberine's lipid-lowering effects are linked to its regulation of intestinal microbiota, particularly BSH-producing bacteria.
results_summary: Berberine supplementation significantly reduced hepatic triglyceride and cholesterol levels, downregulated lipogenesis and proinflammatory cytokines, and increased beneficial bacteria abundance, particularly BSH-producing strains. However, combining berberine with antibiotics diminished these benefits, suggesting microbiota-dependent mechanisms.
population_specificity: Zebrafish (Danio rerio) fed experimental diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects and mechanisms of berberine combined with JPYSHZF on obese PCOS rats, focusing on hormone levels, glucose/lipid metabolism, and ovarian function.
results_summary: Berberine with JPYSHZF improved sex hormone balance, reduced lipid levels, enhanced glucose metabolism, and activated the PI3K/AKT pathway, ameliorating PCOS-like symptoms in obese rats.
population_specificity: Obese rats modeled for polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective effects of berberine in animal models of ischemic stroke and elucidate its potential mechanisms of action.
results_summary: Berberine significantly reduced infarct volume, improved neurological function, and exhibited anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, anti-apoptotic, and neuroregenerative effects in preclinical models of ischemic stroke.
population_specificity: Animal models of focal cerebral ischemia

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and evaluate berberine-derived compounds for their ability to inhibit human adenovirus (HAdV) replication and explore their antiviral mechanisms.
results_summary: Berberine and its analogs demonstrated anti-HAdV activity by inhibiting viral replication through downregulation of the MAPK signaling pathway, particularly ERK activation. 13-methylberberine chloride showed the highest selectivity among tested compounds.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Berberine (BBR) enhances the therapeutic effects of Sorafenib (SOR) in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) and to elucidate the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: BBR enhanced SOR's proliferation-inhibitory effects, apoptosis, and ROS generation in vitro and in vivo, with the synergistic effect dependent on AMPK activation and mTOR pathway inhibition. BBR showed a stronger synergistic effect with SOR compared to metformin (MET).
population_specificity: BEL-7402 and Huh7 cell lines, and tumor xenograft models (no human subjects).
interactions: Synergistic interaction with Sorafenib noted; no other interactions mentioned.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of berberine-loaded nanoliposomes in targeting and treating glioblastoma by enhancing solubility, bioavailability, and therapeutic impact.
results_summary: The study found that berberine-loaded nanoliposomes significantly disrupted glioblastoma cell metabolism, induced autophagy and apoptosis, and suppressed the MAPK signaling pathway, leading to potent anti-cancer effects. The formulation demonstrated high loading efficiency, optimal particle size, and controlled release over 48 hours.
population_specificity: U-87 glioblastoma cells (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify and elucidate the direct molecular targets of berberine to better understand its multifaceted pharmacological mechanisms.
results_summary: The study identified 13 molecular targets of berberine, including FtsZ, QacR, BmrR, PLA2, RamR, NEK7, and MET, through co-crystal structure analysis, target fishing, molecular docking, and SPR.
